loop:
    test everything
    get bored
    loop:

nt stuff"

    unt=
il what "can't break" breaks

So said  john.link@...  on  2003-=
02-04 --------------------

>> If your method does nothing to delegate to s=
omeone else, then
testing
>> your method is the same as testing the method =
to which the
>> implementation delegates; therefore, test the delegate, and=
 not the
>> current method. The only thing that can break is an invalid (nu=
ll)
>> reference, and you've probably testing for that somewhere else.
>> 
=
>
>I followed that path until I was bitten some day: When delegating more
t=
han
>one method - eg in a wrapper - I often code the delegation methods by
=
>typing
>in the first method, copying this method as often as needed and th=
en
>renaming
>method names and delegation calls. Doing that without tests -=
 and
without a
>pair coder - I introduced two nasty bugs... This becomes ev=
en more of
an
>issue when the interface of both delegate and delegee grows,=
 I let the
IDE
>create
>the method stub and evetually forget to fill in the=
 method body. 
>
>Has someone detected a fool-proof (Johannes-proof) way of=
 writing
>delegation
>code to prevent that kind of error? I guess delegatio=
n should part of
the
>language spec the same way implementation inheritance=
 is. For
instance,
